subject: Business
title: Pre-Mortem: Imagining Failure in Advance
description: A quick, practical guide to Pre-Mortem: Imagining Failure in Advance.

hook.text: Before launching, ask: 'Imagine this project failed spectacularly. Why?' The answers are gold.

buildup.text: Gary Klein developed the pre-mortem: assume failure has already happened and work backward to identify causes.

discovery.text: It overcomes groupthink by giving people permission to voice doubts they'd normally suppress.

twist.text: Post-mortems happen after damage is done. Pre-mortems prevent the damage before it starts.

climax.text: Teams that run pre-mortems identify 30% more potential risks than teams that use standard planning.

punchline.text: Imagine the worst before you start. Then build so it can't happen.

quiz.question: How does a pre-mortem differ from a post-mortem?
options: A pre-mortem imagines failure before launch; a post-mortem analyzes it after
A pre-mortem is less detailed than a post-mortem
Pre-mortems are only used in medicine
